8pMTtoUWzZoNJ39d6VKKsA.text: All hipster hype and apathetic service. They have a seemingly simple menu to choose from, but it took one confused college student taking up so much time to place their order, that I had to leave because 25 minutes of my break had already passed by. No other patrons were in the store at the time - not even eating (never a good sign). And 5 other employees standing at the counter filling plastic ramekins with sauces, not willing to help anyone me standing there - READY to order. Whack.   I went in to finally try the Noodles & Tofu for lunch after hearing about all of the hype from fellow vegans - but I will never know how it tastes because I never got waited on. Nor will I ever return, since no one that worked there acknowledged my presence in the first place (not even a "hello"), or apologized for the obscene wait.  Eff this entire hipster establishment.

x19Xv9bqLYK1_tZMKxn7FA.text: The food was mediocre, maybe 2.5 stars worth compared to other Korean options in the city. But I gave them one star because the place looks like it should be fast, since they have all of the ingredients already cooked and out and just need to put it in a bowl. Somehow it took them over 45 minutes to accomplish that. At about 45 minutes I went up to see what was happening and they said they had one of my two meals ready but were waiting on beef for the second, even though it was supposed to be chicken anyway. They still managed to forget the tempura.

EdSua_ktS2eRvp5UJzJ2lA.text: Delicious, quick, and absolutely adorable inside. This place is set up to create your own box meal where you chose from a base (rice, glass noodles, greens), protein (bulgogi, Korean fried chicken, pork and tofu), and some sides. I got the glass noodles, chicken, pickled cucumbers (so good!), they also added some mixed greens and sweet potato tempura. So much food! The staff was so kind. I thought it was awesome that they don't accept tips but rather donations to the humane society. I love the hip vibe with the lighting and succulents. Can't wait to go back again

VR2f5vyW5ZvYaYTWGmY4QA.text: I'm visiting Pittsburgh and I love trying new food places. This place was great! The food was delivered quickly it was very hot, flavorful, and a good portion size. The price was also quite affordable. It was so good I would consider going again during my trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

UCJR3w8xJS8yFZpH8KdftQ.text: A cute space with solid Korean-inspired food.  The food is fresh and informal.  I would come here anytime I'm in the area.

KctDQ3anYbVuWa_B6E-IOA.text: Bae Bae's was exactly what I needed as a mid day pick me up during the week. I don't enjoy eating meat often but the bulgogi was so tender and the owner comped me some veggies because I told him it was my first time there! The Vietnamese coffee was great too. Definitely stop there if you have time, a must-go if you're downtown for lunch.

qnW-q7E0btzVufHECzQPvw.text: Loved the service, environment and food! Grew up with a Korean chef as a mother and the food reminded me of home! I definitely plan on coming back whenever I can!

SGjqEPhGEbo5COxUQVEYaQ.text: This is an interesting and fresh concept to have as a downtown restaurant.  There aren't many options for Korean or Korean inspired food in the area, so I was excited to check Bae's out. They are open for lunch, and then close for two hours and open again for dinner.  I arrived right at 5 when they reopened and they weren't quite ready to be serving yet.  I was still able to order, but had to wait about 15 minutes for my food to be ready.  The staff told me it was because they were new and still getting the hang of things but then told me they had been open for nine weeks (so you think they'd be over growing pains by then).  They did give those of us waiting a few pieces of sweet potato tempura while we were waiting and that was a nice gesture.   I liked that they explained the concept and what each main dish and side were without dumbing it down.  I decided to try the beef with glass noodles and sweet potato tempura.  I wasn't blown away by any of it, but I did really enjoy the meal.  The tempura was probably my favorite part.  They were the right balance of crispy and juicy and had a wonderful flavor.  The glass noodles were just ok.  I though they were fairly bland.  The beef was tender and had a nice amount of flavor with a hint of sweetness.  If I were to visit again I'd probably try the pork belly instead. I was disappointed they didn't have the cucumbers.  Apparently they source them from someplace that doesn't currently have them available.   I did enjoy my meal and will probably visit again.  It was filling and a nice mix of flavors.  I just thought almost $14 was a bit steep for the portions that you got.

r08aRDB-bxQvs33zjnvwJg.text: Love and organic options. Staff was extremely nice not sure what I was expecting but definitely happy with my results

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The seaweed salad is fabulous

ViaLx3VOAtqyZZCtaQAHSQ.text: This restaurant is beautiful. It gives you a little break from the city. It's full of plants and there is space to seat inside and outside (the greenhouse is gorgeous). We asked for a plate with noodles and Vietnamese coffee, both were delicious. We'll definitely come back

yMYDVbFaT93td290CrQ_wg.text: Friendly staff, local ingredients, and super environmentally friendly!! They also are a great benefit to the local community with great, fresh authentic food made daily!!

r_7JtjHUbFhrRsRjWfcemA.text: I brought my Uma in. We are always looking for authentic Korean food so we don't have to do all the work. IT WAS DELICIOUS! We shocked the young man at the counter when we both ordered two meals (left overs!) the bento box presentation, the fresh ingredients and made to order hot foods were fantastic. I troll Insta to see what's new all the time!!

0FMkkMNbXezvA8QpxTD8AA.text: Bae Bae's was delicious! A few friends and I went here for dinner while in town and we were not disappointed. I had the Bulgogi with tempura vegetables. Everything was prepared well. It is a casual restaurant, the staff is friendly, and you don't have to wait long for your food. I would definitely come here again!

fDdPvVS-NZc0ST_Znuwnig.text: Had the fried chicken and some of my wife's bulging I with rice and kimchi. Fantastic.  Worth the hassle of finding parking downtown. Would have been nice if the sauce for the fried chicken was on top (I ate half of it needlessly sauce-less) but everything was great

Snx833ckGuUGXH-h6yVJCA.text: Been going to Bae Bae's since they opened and I can say it's one of my favorite restaurants I've ever been too!! I'm vegan and they have great options for me, although I wish they had tofu skins more often it's my favorite! But their plum sauce is to die for and I love the boba tea! I love going there with my friends because there's options for all of us and all our diets. The hospitality there is also unmatched, I always feel welcomed and at home from the owners and workers, who always address me and my friends by my name and are always so kind. Also very much a fan of how Bae Bae's does their best to use environmentally friendly alternatives for cutlery etc. I love Bae Bae's for their atmosphere and delicious food. I highly recommend!

ZXVXe8C8L8Vd3v1XMzPrcA.text: Bae Bae's Kitchen is one of the best places to eat in Pittsburgh hands down! You can taste the freshness of ingredients in everything on the menu. You left feeling very satisfied, but not overly full! Highly recommend trying if you haven't gone.

wru7UhibMiQhfNL_6zcyyQ.text: Where do I start? Bae Bae's is my FAVORITE spot to eat in Pittsburgh! I am a regular customer there and I love everything!!! The interior and decorations inside make me feel like I'm in Narnia sometimes. That might sound a little too dramatic but you have to go there to feel the atmosphere. It's not your traditional restaurant with waiters and waitresses. It's kind of like a Chipotle, but the food is WAY better and you wont feel guilty about it. Korean Fried Chicken (KFC) is my go to protein. Dont be swayed by the "fried" aspect because it absolutely wont make you feel greasy and gross. Everything at Bae Baes is made fresh and is local, sustainable and organic. Their kimchi is SO GOOD and has the right amount of spice and tanginess. I can eat it everyday. What's my go-to order, you ask? Rice, KFC, Cabbage kimchi, with a side of spicy mayo. You will not regret it, trust me. Also, their cheese wontons are mouthwatering   Bae Baes is a little on the pricey side, but the amount of food they give you is WELL worth the price. GO TO BAE BAES ASAP!

hzagIMmWaQWpjh_w8kD5Vg.text: I had the vegan options for dinner and it was filling and yummy.   They even gave me an extra side for free just because.  The staff is friendly and family operated.     They do not accept tips and instead donate that "tip" money to a local animal charity.   I love that.  The restaurant has a quiet and not overwhelming atmosphere.  I'm definitely going back and I hope that they thrive as a business and stay open for years.

zVFg46VK4DmCzJAmmuo4nw.text: The food here is so good!  My husband and I stopped in for a quick dinner between work and a theater show, and really enjoyed the food and the decor (especially all the plants!).  We both had the glass noodles, one with the crispy tofu and tempura vegetables, and one with the spicy chicken special and spicy crab salad.  The tofu was perfectly crispy on the outside but super juicy on the inside.  They both also came with a salad of mixed greens, and it was a lot of food.  The menu is somewhat limited, so it's not a place we would go all the time, but everything was delicious and the staff was so nice that it's definitely worth revisiting.

aPfXyLjHGFE8tTTdY44GOg.text: Just visited this place for the first time with a sizable group. Fell in love, will be back. Every thing about this place makes the difference. The ambiance, the clean tasting food and the great service. I don't usually write reviews, but this place deserves one. Try it if you haven't, it's worth the hassle of finding parking close by.

7SOLlLIHBbO_KgAltH7fVA.text: Great little lunch spot downtown with friendly service and delicious food!  You can build your own dish by choosing a starch, protein and a side. I went with the glass noodles, Korean fried chicken and a seaweed salad. Everything is pre-cooked and ready to serve as you create your dish. It was quite filling for $12!  I am really looking forward to coming back and trying the Bulgogi!

7_QsHwvXxbLTpx53TrZRog.text: The outside of the restaurant is very unassuming, we actually walked passed it trying to find the location. The store front is small, they have seating in a back room. The inside is nicely designed, very trendy. Based on reviews and the look of the place I was very excited to try the food. I got noodles, bbq pork and bean sprouts along with a Thai tea boba. We waited for fresh noodles and pork to be made. I was very let down by my meal. I can't do very spicy foods and unfortunately you can't customize your order that way. The noodles were very spicy as was the pork which I couldn't even eat. I was not confident that the pork was fully cooked, plus it was mostly fat! I love Thai tea and I love bubble tea, together I was hoping it would be a nice treat but the beverage was watered down and tasteless. This place really let me down. I will say I like that they collect their tips and donate them to the Humane society.

shKqk227w4Da1ktNs7GXww.text: In Pittsburgh for a convention and had to check out Bae Bae's for dinner yesterday after I saw it on Yelp. The food was so delicious that we came back again tonight. CUo74qUdcdSLdAshcCBhEg.text: I am completely obsessed with this place.  I go at least once every two weeks!  No judging!   1.  The individuals that work here are super nice! 2. Which should really be #1 the food is amazing! I tired everything but the tofu and my favorite are their pork meatballs when they have them.The meatballs are always moist and not dry.  I don't know what sauce is on them but it is tasty!   The KFC ( Korean Fried Chicken) is so moist and juicy.  The wasabi honey sauce has a nice kick and opens my sinuses. 2GDDURbFH8jBUly4ThQwuA.text: Great little restaurant and takeout in Pittsburgh.  I ended up coming here twice during a three day trip. e1XyAdwWqAx1FqGum1UDaw.text: I was strolling downtown and came upon bae baes kitchen so I stopped in for lunch. The staff explained how to order and everything that was available to choose from. I chose glass noodles, two giant pork meatballs in Asian sauce, cucumber kimchi, and tempura sweet potatoes. The box also came with a side salad. The meal was enormous and worth the $12. I enjoyed the flavor of the sauce on the pork, but the actual meat could have been more tender and seasoned. The cucumber kimchi and sweet potatoes were both tasty as well. I thought about saving some for a second meal but I ate the whole thing. They had some other tasty sounding proteins like spicy fried chicken, pork ribs, tofu etc.. I will definitely go back. I was excited to see a new lunch spot added downtown.

1Mh7N8jA-2Mrb9twOFES7g.text: I was walking around downtown showing a friend some things about Pittsburgh. We walked by and had to take a peek. 5gFVcZhK9WPhRBJB1EkNTQ.text: 4.5 stars really. The food was AMAZING and portion size made both me and my boyfriend full. cTW7H8E_gzyJEvlqaRkpYg.text: The plants in the window always caught my eye at this establishment. I'm really happy to have finally tried it for lunch with a coworker.   Atmosphere 10/10: Cozy, vibrant and relaxed. The plants definitely made the restaurant seem very hipster. I also really appreciated that the dining room was decorated with hearts, reds and pinks for Valentine's Day.   Food: 9/10: I ordered the bulgogi with the veggie tempura and also cheese wontons. The food comes in a cute box and everything was portioned well. There was so much flavor and texture to the food. I really liked how they included some greens to the dish to help further mix up the texture. The breading on the tempura was grainy and tasty. I was a little nervous that the tempura would get soggy by the time I got back to my office; I was pleasantly surprised when I felt crispiness still. The cheese wontons could've have been better in my opinion.  The sauce was very flavorful and I definitely felt the hear along with sweetness.  However, the wontons themselves were very crispy and filled perfectly.. I just wanted more somehow. I'm not sure if the wontons are worth $5.   Service 9/10: the service here is great! I appreciate how you order your food first at the cute little corner and wait for your food afterwards. I waited about 12 minutes for my food however, it was during the lunch rush. The man that helped me behind the counter was super smiley and answered the questions that I had. Once service slowed down, he even brought out my coworker's food to him and double checked whether or not I wanted a bag to carry it all.   Overall, I'd absolutely recommend this place. The place is vibrant and full of life. The customer service is great and I felt genuinely cared for and the food is very good!

fh91i4_R62NgdNudCMtNFw.text: I had been meaning to check out Bae Bae's Kitchen for a few months now. I walked in on a Wednesday about 10 minutes after they opened at 11:30am and there were already like 5 people in line! I could tell they were popular. The food was very good. I got their noodle bowl with tofu and veggies. I also got a thai iced tea. The meal was somewhat expensive, coming it at around $20 with tip. However it was very enjoyable and everything comes in biodegradable containers/forks/etc, which was a nice touch! Their food is also organic!   The atmosphere of the restaurant was soooo cute. They had small tables scattered through the front and back of the restaurant. You walked up to the counter to order and they called out your number when your food was ready. I took mine to go but ended up sitting right outside the restaurant in their community seating area. It was connected to the restaurant but open to the public which was a nice, community-focused, touch.   Overall, the atmosphere will take me back and I'll try a different protein in my next bowl!

_ovliuk7g7FDtUl_VExvOQ.text: The hype is real. I started going to Bae Bae's for lunch, and I cannot go anywhere else now. The food is pricey and the wait may be long, but it's well worth it. Excellent quality. Excellent service.   I even ordered catering for my office (70 people) from them. Picked it up AT opening (11:30a) without a hitch. The team definitely had to come in early, but I never felt like an inconvenience. Excellent communication and attention to detail.   Bae bae's is a Pittsburgh MUST.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

VbtUV-rlXw9k3awcvLxPoQ.text: Went back to Bae Bae's for lunch and it is as good as I remembered. There's a reason there's a line for lunch and it's more than worth the wait (and the price). Bae Bae's has seating in the front and back and additional spots can be found at small tables in the front during the nicer times of the year. Bae Bae's has a nice modern/hip feel to it, but it's the food that keeps you coming back.  You can pick the rice, glass noodles, a protein (bulgogi, Korean fried chicken, chicken stir fry, or tofu), and a side which varies daily (although the cucumber kimchi is there everyday and it's awesome). The portions are very generous and the noodles are filling and delicious (I always get them). The bulgogi is perfectly cut, cooked, seasoned, and sauced and goes perfect with the noodles and salad. The Korean fried chicken is cooked and fried and two full breasts are served (plenty of food). The Korean fried chicken is also served with a honey wasabi which is served on the side and can be poured on or dipped.

dgwuvOmC4XY3TcEYxdEg-g.text: This place is a great fast casual Asian food option in downtown Pittsburgh! I got the beef with their purple rice and it was very filling and delicious. The beef is the least spicy of the meat options- it's really not spicy at all, but has good flavor! It was served with greens and then I picked the Napa cabbage kimchi as my side. The cabbage kimchi was good. The person working the register was very helpful in telling me about the meat options and in helping me decide what I wanted. I'd definitely come back to try more stuff on the menu!

O_8npayPC4_W2hxFb5yJyw.text: YES. We need something like this in my hometown.  It's a great concept.  Quick Korean food.  Following in what seems to be the trend of "building your bowl" or in this case "build your box" type restaurants, Bae Bae's Kitchen is a great find in this area of the city.  I was staying at the Hampton Inn on Smallman, and this was only an 8 minute walk.  Considering the trend towards bars and higher end dining in general over here, I found this to be a welcome discovery traveling with my 18 year old charge.  First of all, when you enter into the restaurant, the smell of Korean food floods your nostrils and you're in culinary heaven.  I love that smell... and it's still in my nose now. (unless that's the leftover wafting over from the counter...)  I went with a rice, marinated beef, and napa kimchee combination and it was DELICIOUS.  There's nothing really more to say about that.  The flavors were strong but not overpowering.  The black sesame seeds add a hint of flavor that I always love.  Student went with the fried glass noodle, Korean Fried Chicken (KFC) and seaweed salad.  She wasn't in love with it, but reported that it wasn't too spicy, which generally means it's OK.  She also wasn't a fan of the plum sauce, as she felt it was too sweet.  It was a substitution for a wasabi sauce I suggested she not eat.  Thai tea for me with tapioca pearls to boot.  You also cant' go wrong there.  Student went with a milk tea.  Her favorite.    But by far my favorite aspect of our visit... the decor.  I called it "cute" to the guy taking our order.  But cute isn't really the word for it.  It's WHIMSICAL.  I loved the dainty, garden-like environs that transport you somewhere magical.  And the added touches for Christmas were apparent too.  So thoughtfully done.  I bet others think it could be overdone, but really, it's something beautiful.  I just wanted to sit there in the front window and enjoy the evening.    This location closes at 8, so if you're staying in a nearby hotel, plan accordingly.  But definitely check it out!

Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Box with rice, marinated beef and napa kimchi. Mmm

AtxsYxlaRWw84jBLDTxPSQ.text: Got the fried crispy tofu with a side of veggie tempura over a bed of mixed greens (almost healthy, right??). The tofu was creamy on the inside and crisp on the outside - a very good fried tofu! I appreciate the chunky serving, too, as sometimes vegetarian food doesn't keep me as full. The vegan plum sauce they have over it tastes almost exactly like oyster sauce, which is a compliment in my book. The veg tempura was also tasty and decidedly distinct from Japanese tempura, though I wish I'd gotten a little more with my order. Altogether pretty good, if a slightly pricier option for Pittsburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Crispy tofu and veggie tempura over mixed greens

Hs2k95YGM9SwB136sNLUeQ.text: I am not one to have favorites but Bae Bae's Kitchen is, of recent, my UTMOST FAVE place to eat. Why you ask?  First of all, how dare you ask that --  Second of all, WHY NOT? Not only is this restaurant sustainable but it also accommodates to every lifestyle/diet!  As a new vegan, I seriously appreciate the options at Bae Bae's! It is especially hard to be a Korean vegan because fish/fish products seem to creep into every Korean dish (including kimchi) -- but Bae Bae makes it easy for me to pick what I want to eat.  [Food] My non-vegan friends and I went and created our own bowls. I got the tofu with plum sauce over glass noodles. The tofu is crispy on the outside and just the right amount of sweet each bite. The glass noodles are seriously addictive. Alongside the main meal, I was given greens, which perfectly cut through the heartiness of the meal with its freshness and acidity. The kimchi (vegan) tasted amazing. Personally, I found the portion sizes just right. There was enough food for me to get full without concern of food coma-ing. My friends agreed. They enjoyed their food as much as I did, if not more.  [Service] The people here are so frickin wholesome. They definitely put their hearts in their work. Each meal is packed with care. The cashier is super mellow and kind. Very patient. Everyone has a warm demeanor, very sweet.  [Atmosphere] The interior of the place has the power to heal souls -- the green life, lights and thoughtful decor make for a safe haven. I love the amount of care put into this place. They even put up Christmas decorations. You're bound to smile stepping inside. Bae Bae's even has outdoor seating (for warmer days, I'm assuming) and a cute little garden outside.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. This place is so cute
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Christmas decorations!
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cute tree

NOTq4P1sGNdUGwnLqddv7w.text: I work downtown and one of my co-workers kept referencing Bae Bae's and their "addicting" Korean fried chicken. All I can say is that I'm only upset I haven't eaten their food earlier in life.   The restaurant itself is cozy, quaint, and I love all of the greenery and mini terra cotta pots decorating the walls. In the spring and summer, there is an outdoor alcove where you can enjoy their food and take in the city's daily activity.  The food is simple but familiar, yet very difficult to describe to those who haven't tried. You can truly feel the love that is put into each dish. I had to drag my husband here on a weekend and now he never stops talking about their food as well.  My favorite items are the Korean Fried Chicken, their Bulgogi Mandu (a fried dumpling with bulgogi beef and japchae noodles), and their daikon radish Kimchi. My husband loves the handmade dumplings with chili oil and veggie tempura. I have not been lucky enough to try their featured desserts yet but I always walk away with an Earl Grey milk tea with bubbles in my hand.   I will say that I don't necessarily get to enjoy this at lunch given my personal work schedule but this is one of my favorite spots for an early dinner or a weekend lunch. They are also available through UberEats but I highly suggest you experience the food in person. There are some restaurants that speak to your soul and Bae Bae's is one of them.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Earl Grey Milk Tea with tapioca bubbles // Korean fried chicken // homemade dumplings with chili oil

7nnA5qZmGmoYE26g2JpdGg.text: I've been waiting to go to this place for forever, and I'm so glad that I did!! Oh my gosh. So good. I did the build your own and got the spicy stir fried chicken, purple rice, and sesame zucchini. It was all AMAZING. The chicken was so tender and such good quality. They also don't skimp at all-the quantities were very large. My friend got the KFC (Korean fried chicken) and it was also cooked soooo good! The man at the front was so kind. I wish I had gotten his name, he was so sweet and informative. I wish this place was closer...I truly can't wait to go back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

rcSMCraOqzwchaT5-7UP5A.text: The decor is very cute and feel very fresh!! The food was ok with limited options. The portion is big but chicken is bit dry, bulgogi beef is better.   Thai ice tea is very refreshing, specially under the weather of 36+. Will go back again if I visit Pittsburgh again.

30NxA5ucbvV5vD4AB3d3tA.text: Bae Bae's Kitchen is one of the few (if not only) Asian food place that's worth going to in downtown Pittsburgh.   It's a fast casual BYO (build your own) concept. You can choose either rice, noodles, or salad, protein, and a side dish. Each plate comes with a salad as well. The options that they usually have are bulgogi--a marinated beef, KFC--Korean fried chicken, and tofu. They also have specials which they'll post on Instagram!   My favorite is definitely the bulgogi and rice combo with whatever housemade kimchi they have on special. Literally sooo freaking good. They also have a lot of vegan-friendly options for friends who don't eat meat.   Also can we talk about the bubble tea there?? It's all house brewed and delicious AND they offer almond + soy milk for those of us who can't have milk. If you couldn't tell, I'm all around obsessed with Bae Bae's.  There is usually a line literally out the door, but the wait is worth it! The restaurant is super sustainably focused with wooden utensils and cardboard straws, and it's super cool to see a place in Pittsburgh really focus on that. The atmosphere inside is also really cute and dreamy with a ton of twinkling lights and flowers, so if it's not packed, I would actually recommend eating there. This is one of my staples in Pittsburgh and I definitely find myself coming back here all the time!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bubble tea!
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lychee lemonade
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. One of the BYO plate combos!

ZjDWuwI5d9n-4VvTktRUKw.text: This restaurant is exactly as described by others. It has a small front and a short menu. Nothing wrong with either.   You pick from various items. I picked the glass noodles with bulgogi beef. Then the seaweed salad on the side. We also got the cheese wontons and I got the sparkling strawberry lemonade to drink. My husband got the spicy chicken special with rice and the vegetable tempura. Milk tea to drink.   All of the food comes packaged to go, even if you are staying in. Everything was good.  They give you a little side salad with a light dressing on the side. The sauce on the beef was really yummy.   My only complaint is the prices, which seem a bit high. We paid $40 for the meal. $4 for three cheese wontons. But the food is very good.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sparkling strawberry lemonade and milk tea
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cheese wontons with spicy mayo

XVDJ6-4LuTNYEnKzOwzeWQ.text: This is one of my new favorite vegan/vegetarian eateries in Pittsburgh!! This charming Kitchen is located right in the heart of downtown and is easily accessible by bus. The abundance of plants and lights throughout the store gives a lovely whimsical vibe to the dining experience.   The menu itself is pretty small as you base your meal around building a bowl with either salad, rice, or noodles. I got the stir fried glass noodles with veggies, crispy tofu, and vegetable tempura. The plum sauce drizzled over my bowl tied the meal together with its bursting flavor.   I came with a friend who is gluten-free and she was pretty satisfied with her meal as well since there were comparable options for her bowl (rice, tofu, kimchi, but no sauce).   No matter what you get, you will probably leave the store feeling full and content, knowing that you are eating local and eating healthy!

Lc8oGKD7VT_6SVMF-0SzMg.text: Bae Bae's is such a great spot in Downtown Pittsburgh. I wasn't sure what to expect because I have never had Korean food before. I loved Bae's Bae's!   I went with some other local foodies around 6pm on a Wednesday evening. There were plenty of tables available in the back of the restaurant- but we grabbed one up front. It's very warm and welcoming in the restaurant. The staff is so friendly and knowledgeable.   I ordered the Korean Fried Chicken special with rice and tempura vegetables. This special also comes with a side salad. I also ordered a side of cheese wontons- everything was incredible. I also tried the beef wontons and they were also very good.   You gotta go & it out! I will definitely be back to visit Bae Bae's again soon! Run, don't walk to this restaurant!

5A9ctcyH-Oyx93trbAWnjg.text: Amazing food. They even have bubble tea to go with the amazing lunch! Love the little area for seating outside by the street.

np1iSfyb2fNi34koaPNxVw.text: We went here for lunch. Nice Korean country ambiance feel with the small garden up front. There is seating up front and also in the back. clean restrooms in the back to the left.   As far as food goes, we ordered the fried chicken with noodles with reg kimchi side & bulgogi with salad with kimchi cucumbers side. The noodles are japchae, which was tasty. The fried chicken was a cutlet. For some reason I was expecting little Korean chicken drumsticks (gan bok ki). The chicken cutlet was tasty, but a bit dry. It could also use a kick. The bulgogi was good but not delicious. The sides were both excellent. Sorry, im being a little picky with the overall meat flavors.   They do have drinks in a cooler. I had the blood orange and my wife had the bottled green tea.   The overall price was to be expected.   I would give it 3.25 stars. Enough to try it again, but not something I would want to eat every week for work.

-Sx7pUrgsCdbuVRE66SJZQ.text: Highly recommend Bae Bae's kitchen for catering. I needed food for a party of 35-40 people and Bae Bae's Kitchen catered for us. Food was delicious. Most popular at our party were the KFC, kimbap (ordered bulgogi and tofu versions) and the cucumber kimchi. Lots of great options on their menu for vegetarians too.

FVbLiJuhOA6aeZOnpYCmHQ.text: Stopped here for a lunch with vegan options and was very impressed! Tried the veggie tempura and the tofu bowl with noodles. Really good flavors and sauces, with beautiful decor to boot!

6fbZUKO2yftXvfnhZ8w3ZA.text: As a former vegan, I still really appreciate when a place offers delicious veg options-- Bae Bae's definitely does! The food is delicious (I'm a big fan of the cucumber kimchi and noodles) and the service is always friendly. I was sorry to see the prior place that inhabited this space go, because that too was delicious, but this has proven to be a wonderful replacement. I think it's definitely up there as one of the best spots to get lunch Downtown!

YeAk77aVU3KqakAAYxqViw.text: Given that I work downtown, it is really exciting to see new ethnic restaurants popping up. Like other reviewers have noted, it is a pretty tiny establishment and it gets very busy during lunch. While this is a great thing for the business, it can create customers to become antsy if service is slow.   My co-workers and I stopped in on a Monday at 11:30 when the doors opened. This is a food court style restaurant and you make your selections as you go. The menu isn't overwhelming which makes ordering less time consuming. I ordered the traditional Korean bulgogi and glass noodles. The beef was very tender and perfectly seasoned. If you are building your own plate, I would highly recommend choosing the bulgogi as your protein. The box comes with a side of bok choy and another side that you can choose. The bok choy was flavorless and they were out of cucumber salad. This was a little disappointing since it was a Monday morning and they should have been stocked up for the week.   Also, I would like to comment on the person that was preparing the boxes also had to cover the register at one point. There was someone different on the register, but she had to prepare a large order of milk teas and couldn't do both. This caused a back up because no one was preparing the boxes while he was covering the register. I think they have some kinks to work out with the service line, but overall I was pleased with my bulgogi.

53z8ue9vsKpby5ZkFETp4w.text: Amazing vegan options! Had the tofu and rice noodles. I'll be back here many times for sure.

4V9DgEijHehuqTa0Yb_W1A.text: I loved this place! It's small so seating might be tough for larger parties, but the atmosphere is really cute. They clearly put a lot of work into decorating, there's adorable little succulent plants and lights everywhere. I built a plate with Korean fried chicken (so good, the skin was perfectly crispy. I tried the bulgogi and this was better in my opinion), which came with a wasabi dipping sauce, and glass noodles with salad. It comes with one side but the server gave me two, cucumber kimchi and potato salad! The server today was amazing, he was so friendly and upbeat and even gave us free sweet potato tempura because it wasn't available when we ordered. He also gave me extra boba in my Vietnamese coffee. Very happy with everything!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Korean fried chicken with wasabi dipping sauce, glass noodles, salad, cucumber kimchi, potato salad

8TSHrwBBlU_sjb_kUpBTnA.text: It's delicious. I highly recommend. The ribeye bulgogi was so tasty! I loved the rice and salad as well. Double thumbs up!

mlkzObPQ4VGjeXZlROi-Aw.text: A cute little cafe vibe, the plants in the window and overall atmosphere make for a lovely place for you to eat your meal. There is limited seating, but the back of the store has seating with long tables that would be ideal for bigger parties. The menu is rather limited, but the components of each meal is done well and packs a symphony of tastes and flavors as you can mix and match a protein, a pairing (rice, glass noodles, or salad) and a side dish.  I chose the bulgogi with rice and a side dish of kimchi cucumbers while my friend chose the Korean Fried Chicken with rice and tempura vegetables. I also got a Thai iced tea and added boba to it (which they gave me plenty!). The fried chicken was moist and perfectly fried and the wasabi-honey sauce that came with it was good. The bulgogi was well marinated; however, my only complaint was that they added too many onions and not enough beef.   The next time I go downtown, I will definitely be coming back here to try the other choices!

DGuHh7IU3FAIglEfX_SFCw.text: Bae Bae's is a welcome addition to the downtown lunch scene! I love both the beef and fried chicken options. I think the portion size is totally fine for the price point, and I love that they offer milk tea. The decor inside is super cute, too!  I go there a good bit, and my one complaint is that they often run out of things midway through the lunch hour. I don't mind, I typically will just get something else, but it would be nice to have more options. As others have said the line can get long, but I do think they work through it fairly quickly!

axhX-b7wpuIRucq17rkNgA.text: Excellent customer service. Was very confused on what I was eating. That's my fault. But the KFC meal was bland no flavor at all. The Salad provided was lettuce nothing else. The spicy chicken was great. Very flavorful. And the potato and cheese cake was good as well. I will definitely come back just ask more questions and never get the KFC meal

XXeKAU7xnSFuB2dqkKT_Hw.text: Other reviews were fairly accurate. Some quick things to note. It's downtown so it's hard to find parking at any time, also there is no sign above the restaurant. As for the food, I had the Korean Fried Chicken with rice and tempura sweet potatoes. The chicken was cooked well but not seasoned enough, rice was perfect, and sweet potatoes surprisingly tasty. I would go back. But honestly it didn't blow me away. It's a bit on the high side for lunch, ~$13-15.

hiCx_v4fQatI73hRdYDq3g.text: Sort of pricey korean-fusion food, makes sense since they offer vegan options, which is why it probably didn't satisfy me the way a good ol' spread of banchan and real (yes not the katsu-kind) KFC does.  My fault for expecting otherwise, I knew the photos looked too healthy!  Really small container of kimchi :( No kimbap, apparently that's made by owners whim, which is actually the reason I went. :(  Service was wonderful though, girl behind counter took the time to explain all the items.  My (katsu-like) KFC was made fresh with a cool wasabi-honey sauce.  It's nice but I'm team sweet-soy or gochujang KFC forever.  I think its a great place if you're looking for some lighter-fare or korean-vegan, which is rare.  Not for me though! I welcome diabetes.

lDq5BxgQ0NJIP2amcDVRmQ.text: This place is adorable! I had the KFC chicken and the wasabi honey was a great take on a hot honey. The Kim chi was also delicious. Great concept on the donations instead of tips.  The portions are huge and I would definitely return!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

e63YgsxlVP-4UlvhkK8uGw.text: I love this place for KFC! It was $13 for a lot of good food. The service there is really nice they explain everything and how to order and they have samples of all the food so you can see what everything looks like. A meal also comes with a heavy heaping of salad that is really fresh touch. I'd recommend going with the noodles rather than the rice because the rice is plain.

oocS6-TpW9hEeI6zdo0WQg.text: Intimate setting but with enough seating. We got the bulgogi plate with glass noodles and kimchi. Everything was super tasty and very fresh. The salad dressing was a little strong, so if you're not a huge fan of vinaigrette maybe ask for that on the side. They do donations instead of tips which I think is pretty awesome!

3X80UNzp0dgZGe-_960aaA.text: Best place downtown period! Great friendly staff and everything is fresh made. There are cheaper places to eat but the quality they offer is well worth a few extra dollars! Unique and tasty when you're tired of the same old food!

Z-X0lCmtxYa8witdjC_BTg.text: I have been looking for more easy lunch places downtown.  This place had a super simple quick service style menu with even a more friendlier staff.  They let me in early the other day so I wouldn't have wait outside in the cold.  I highly recommend this place!

R8gJevPgRfXaHSH_owMzPw.text: Must try!!! Bomb af!!! Came to visit fam and needed actual vegan food besides salads, lol. From the San Francisco/Bay Area where the Asian food choices are countless, and I must say that this Korean food is bomb af. I had the fried broccoli and sweet potatoes, fried tofu, and noodles, which came with a big salad. Food was VERY tasty and the portions were large. Daniel was very knowledgeable and hooked us up with some fried vegetables because my mom was new to Korean. The customer service was amazing and the quality was beyond expectations! You must try it!

6tVYTUeJ8vHgJjFRNbKTqA.text: This little spot was surprisingly delicious! I ordered the BBQ beef with glass noodles and enjoyed every bite. Also highly recommend their side order of cheese wanton.. Very tasty!

N5auIJ9b1R4niUIkOKnoQA.text: I can not recommend Bae Bae's Kitchen enough! The ambiance is very nice and cute. Every corner of the store is IG picture worthy! I recently found out I am allergic to dairy. It was really nice walking in and being able to order from the menu freely! I love that everything is locally and sustainability sourced, no MSG, no preservatives, and no artificial flavors or colors.  I built my own bowl with noodles (Japchae), bulgogi (marinated grass fed beef), and cucumber kimchi as a side. My meal was absolutely delicious! I really like that the bowl is also served with a salad! Portions are very large as well. I packed the rest and it will be a nice snack. This meal really hit the spot! The sweet potato fries were extremely crispy and delicious. The pork and kimchi dumplings in chili oil was very flavorful! My only complaint was the dumplings were slightly over cooked and the dumplings were falling apart a little. I like when the dumpling skin has a bite. The employees were all very friendly and helpful! When I asked for hot sauce, I was offered Sriracha and their level 10 hot sauce. They also asked if my friends were Korean and offered us free kimchi!  If you are in the Pittsburgh area, I highly recommend Bae Bae's Kitchen!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bowl with noodles (Japchae), Bulgogi (marinated grass fed beef), and cucumber kimchi

R5izagHwFuqKU9yETllEEQ.text: Overall good experience here. Heard a lot of buzz about this place and got excited to try It. Headed here for lunch and got there around 12:00 sharp-- not wait in line at that time but quickly got busy as we waited for our food. Pretty standard downtown lunch rush. I got the spicy chicken with glass noodles and seaweed salad on the side. We also ordered the Korean fried chicken.   Spicy chicken: I got about a 4-5 spiciness, there is heat but not very hot in my opinion definitely prefer less heat than too much! Glass noodles were so GOOD. Side salad that comes with It good too-- needs more dressing it's a little dry unless you mix the entire box together  KFC: very good! Texture and chicken quality was great! Only complaint was It was an over-flavorful crisp outside which you didn't really notice if you mixed the bowl together.   Overall, good. Not the best thing I've ever tried but everything tasted fresh and relatively healthy. The interior can be a little cramped at peak times but wow was it so cute inside! The ambiance as amazing!!! I was definitely come back. It was a nice change in pace since I haven't seen much Korean food in Pittsburgh. Prices seemed standard for fast casual with the amount of food you get. Could be a little cheaper in my opinion but nonetheless still worth It.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

B37yZafjwu8OW65WCmGlig.text: *MEDIOCRE (Too expensive for the quality)*  Bae bae's kitchen puts an aesthetic element to korean food. The place itself is very cute, with a hallway of fairy lights. However, food was EXPENSIVE and not right off of the stove. When we went, all the food was already prepared and just scooped into a box. Granted, I went within the first couple of month of it's openings and things have changed according to some of my friends. You do get to pick a couple of sides and the whole presentation looks nice. But we all agree that it was not worth the price. You can try it out for yourself.

awS17d5wg4DNNIpnYYDVcQ.text: Absolutely fabulous establishment. When you walk in, the vibe is rustic modern greenhouse (?)... not sure the right way to describe, just know you'll love it.   The staff is always so kind and helpful. I look forward to being greeted by Daniel. He helps us navigate the menu and is always sporting his beautiful smile!   But what good is all the above info if the food sucks? Thankfully, this little gem does not disappoint. I had the KFC dish with noodles and a side of cucumber kimchi. Everything is fresh, hot and delicious!! The crispy chicken is pushed to nirvana level when you use their wasabi honey dipping sauce. I could dip my toes in that sauce and not mind.

oqaAbUuvscb3qmVH2HRWNA.text: I had such high hope for this place. However the food was just lacking flavor. The only things i would go back is for the staff, the drinks, those amazing crispy wings and the cheese wontons.  I did the noodles, and kfc and radish kim chi. You get a lot for the price but the noodles were bland and the chicken was ok. Kim chi was really good. The noodles were missing like some garlic or ginger.   However, O would still go again for the wings alone.

ves4DmGQjC9AcCbYfuIQUQ.text: I walked in here as soon as they opened at 11:30 and since this was my first visit asked directions as to how to order. Once led to the ordering counter I asked the man behind the counter if they had any gluten free items. He said "no, are you celiac?" I replied no but since my reviews are usually tailored to those with dietary restrictions I try to find out.  They do have many vegan options to choose from. This fast casual concept works pretty much the same as what I'm used to: Order a base, then a protein and then a side which is a condiment size container of one of 5 items sitting by the register. I decided upon a salad base but he talked me into getting either a noodle or purple rice base since my meal comes with salad anyway. I decided to try the tofu since it wasn't as spicy with plum sauce. I also ordered as a side the vegetable tempura. With that I ordered a passion mango fruit drink. Needless to say by the time I was done ordering there was a line behind me nearly out the door!  I was given a number and sat down at a table. They have a few tables up front as well as a few in the back. Outside they have a lovely garden veranda to sit under on a hot day if you prefer to eat there. They use semi compostable utensils-the straw and the fork. The knife I had was plastic.  All food is served in "to go" containers. When my number was called I got my two containers and was amazed at the size of the tofu. It looked like they were serving a whole box full of it similar to what I see at the grocery store. The tofu was good however very difficult to cut with that plastic knife. I truly enjoyed my side of seeweed salad and the salad that came with it. I must say the best thing I liked was that passion mango fruit juice. If it wasn't $4.00 a glass I would have bought another one.  The vegetable tempura was also good but since it was fried and covered in sea salt I could taste the spices. I used the soy sauce for dipping it to make it more enjoyable. The purple rice was well-just ordinary rice with a purple color and other things mixed in with it. The meal was a bit messy as well but they had plenty of napkins near their water cooler. On their chalkboard it reads that they source local, sustainable, and all natural products. They even separate your trash from your recycles.  This place depending upon what you get costs pretty much as what you may pay for an average sit down restaurant. This is a very popular lunch spot among the working but it dies down around 12:30 or so.  The good-plenty of vegan options and for the most part well prepared food. Nice outdoor garden and sitting area. The bad-no gluten free options available. A bit pricey. Long lines. Verdict-3.5. Located on the 900 block of Liberty Ave public transportation is available as well as metered and garage parking.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lovely plants decorate the outside
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Ordering and beverage area
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. How you order and the extra items for purchase

ETi8ihderImOuF_EMRRspw.text: This is such a cute little Korean place! It's definitely NOT your typical, ahjumma-owned place.  The interior (AND exterior) is pretty unique. They have a lot of plants and beautiful flowers decorated in and out of the restaurant. Part of the restaurant looks like a mini greenhouse! :D They have outdoor seating options as well as indoor, but it was way too hot to sit outside today.  All the utensils seemed to be biodegradable; the straws are paper and forks were wood(?).   You order like you do at Chipotle where you choose a "base" (rice, noodles, salad), a choice or meat, and a side.  I ordered the rice + spicy chicken + crab salad side and my husband ordered rice + KFC (Korean fried chicken) + bean sprout side. The sides are not that big - they just come in little containers. The food comes in a box with your order and a side salad with soy sauce-based dressing.  The taste of the food was YUM! The portion size was on the bigger side and everything we ordered was very flavorful and delicious.  It wasn't FULLY Korean though (you can definitely tell it's more on the fusion side than the authentic).   All the employees were very nice and friendly too. If I lived in the area, I'd definitely come back again!

To me this meant that the food was probably premade instead of made per order which, since the food is ready so fast was nice, but felt the price was a little steep in consideration of this.  I'll definitely go back!

7ZSrTFBv6GmmEAFjv9cw5A.text: I love this place!! I've been here twice so far and everything I've tried (bulgogi, japchae, Korean fried chicken, Vietnamese iced coffee) has all been super good. Good and flavorful, super crisp chicken, good serving sizes, good variety of stuff when you choose to build one of their little meal box things. I know I've used good way too many times in this review but it's just That Good. Choosing what things to get is always exciting.   The space is very cute too, clean with lots of natural light and a good plants and wood kinda aesthetic.   My only complaints would be that it can get a bit slow when you come at a popular time.

2mVCD7qz9jsp6-LuMUdsgQ.text: Solid clean Korean food.   I ordered a bowl with the bulgogi beef and glass noodles  The beef was pretty well executed. The noodles were springy and chewy. I found the inclusion of salad in the bowl to be odd and offputting. The tempura veggies were well executed with a crisp exterior and just-soft-enough interior.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bulgogi Bowl

z4gwJXQyuwCQyFm6S7EE6g.text: I've seen Bae Bae's kitchen on yelp quite a few times, but I've never gone to try it because it's right in the middle of downtown. Personally, I'd go here way more often if it were in another location (with better parking) because it's not really worth all of the work if you're driving. However, if I'm ever already downtown area for something I'll definitely stop back in. The food was really tasty and the service was excellent!   My first impression upon walking in was that it's beautiful! It's very modern and fresh which gives it a great vibe to sit in and enjoy your meal. At first, it seems small and cramped, but there's actually a back room full of seating too!   The service was excellent. Every single person was kind, helpful, and seemed actually happy to be there, which I don't find very often anymore. One of the employees figured out that we wanted to sit at a table that hadn't been cleaned yet, and she made a serious effort to get it cleaned for us. It was refreshing to see how dedicated they all were!   The food was really tasty. I ordered cheese wontons, and they were delicious (I'm a crab rangoon fanatic, so this means a lot). I also ordered the Korean fried chicken meal with purple rice, and the crab salad. The chicken comes with this wasabi honey sauce, which blew my mind. And the cheese wontons came with a spicy crab cream sauce, which I also thought was pretty good. The crab salad was okay, but I really enjoyed the chicken and rice much more. The sauces really pulled it all together nicely.  One thing I will say is that it can get a bit pricey. You're probably going to spend about $18-25 on your meal, which is a bit out of my comfort zone. I'd go here again if I wanted to splurge a bit, but there are several other more accessible and even cheaper places I could go with Great Asian food. I hope they open up another location!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beautiful decor!
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Korean fried chicken meal with cheese wontons
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Korean Fried Chicken with purple rice, a side salad, and crab salad (not pictured)

-2onsG70GdQHIMYSwx5HCA.text: Have you ever loved a food so much that you've wanted to die? That's this place for me. I would get engaged here, married here, and die here. Lay me to rest out back. I'm not even the biggest Asian/Korean style food fan and they've converted me!   But in all seriousness, what a rootin' tootin' fantastic restaurant this is. I have gotten both the KFC (Korean fried chicken) and the spicy chicken. I love both, but the spicy chicken is my favorite. And when they tell you it's a 7/10 spicy, believe them! You may not think that at first, but by the next morning, you sure will. What a rush.  And do not get me started on their tempura. I didn't even know what a tempura was before Bae Bae's and now I can never look back. Sweet potatoes? Love them. Lightly bread them and back them? LOVE THEM EVEN MORE. Toss some broccoli and mushrooms in there and you've got the holy trinity.   They recently added quinoa to the white rice which made me nervous to change my habit, but gosh darn it they've done it again. They made me like QUINOA!   My only complaint about this place is that I can never seem to get it on food delivery services -- but it usually doesn't matter because I will risk my life to drive downtown anytime for Bae Bae's.   thank you Bae Bae, you scrumptious beast.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. spicy chicken with white rice (and quinoa) and veggie tempura (lightly breaded broccoli, mushrooms, and sweet potatoes)
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spicy chicken with white rice and veggie tempura (lightly breaded mushrooms, broccoli, and sweet potatoes)

71iByteGBhPARxa19mcOEQ.text: This restaurant has its pros and cons. On the pros side, first and foremost, this little spot is very environmentally conscious and it really shows. The use paper straws and biodegradable utensils. The place is also very cute with a ton of plants. Lastly the food seems relatively healthy and fresh. My spicy chicken stir fry was pretty good and had some good flavor.  On he side of the cons, the food seemed to be lacking in flavor. The Korean fried chicken tasted very plain like it hadn't been seasoned. The side salad was also very plain and could use more dressing. The crab salad was ok but I wouldn't order it again and didn't even finish the little bit I was given.  Overall the food was ok but nothing special. It was nice that the restaurant was environmentally friendly, but for a little less than $20 a person it just did not feel like it was worth the price

Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spicy chicken stir fry, rice, salad, and crab salad

getOD4m3ytXPqM3wJcOuuw.text: We came here with a hankering for kimbap because ever since we had it in South Korea last month, we have been craving it. Yelp images led us to believe that Bar Bae's regularly has kimbap, however, it turns out they only served it for a short time as a special.   We were sorely disappointed since that is what we were hoping for, but instead we got a rice and bulgogi plate that was really tasty. The meat tasted just as expected and the other fixings with it were great too. We got a side of crab salad, good, but not amazing. My wife and I shared the meal and it was the perfect amount for us since we weren't incredibly hungry.   Our only complaints were just that the side was only about one forkful, and the meal seems a little on the pricey side.   Hopefully we'll be able to make it back soon for some kimbap!

RTydQqrVtg-yokHZ9jUFMg.text: Bae Bae's has been on my list to try for a long time. The decor creates a wholesome and tranquil ambiance, as it ties together the "cutesy/cafe" vibe with one of nature. You instantly feel relaxed as you walk in and later nourished as you eat great food! Inside they have a range of seating options for different sized groups or individuals. One of my favorite things was their use of sustainable cutlery (i.e non plastic)! They use local ingredients (not sure if all ingredients are local but at least some are).   For my meal I ordered the fried chicken with noodles- it also came with a bit of salad. The portion was huge! I was able to save close to half for lunch the next day. You definitely get a great value for your money. Further, everything tasted SO good. I'd highly recommend getting the cucumber kimchi as the side.  I hesitated to go for a while because I was under the impression that this was only a vegan restaurant (could not tell you why I thought that) but they offer vegan, vegetarian, and meat options so a great choice if you have friends with specific food preferences.   Overall, I cannot wait to return and try more of their menu or reorder this meal. Go and try it for yourself!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried chicken with noodles

QqT8By0WIyUrTHelNarAVQ.text: If I had just found this place before my last day!  I was visiting Pittsburgh and stumbled upon this place.    I found this place to be lively and the staff to be most helpful and patient as it took me a bit to decide and what the ordering process consisted of.  I chose the Purple Rice, Korean Fried Chicken and Seaweed Salad.. and of course the tempting Strawberry Lemonade!  Let me tell you what, the deliciousness that was contained in that box was out of Pittsburgh!  This Steel City eatery delivered up some of the best Korean Inspired food that I've experienced!  I must mention that the strawberry lemonade was the best I've EVER had, no joke!  When I come back to Pittsburgh in 2020, this WILL be my first eatery!

Tl5xZIt2_5tnb2-bZGuWUw.text: Ambiance: 4/5 Cleanliness: 5/5 Food: 5/5 Service: 5/5 Value: 5/5  As a Korean, it's easy to be picky and criticize Korean places. However this place is Awesome. Ordered the bulgogi plate, with cucumber kimchi, which came with a side salad as well. Food felt so clean and not greasy, which many Korean places fall into doing. Loved every bite of each item. Definitely recommend, service was fantastic as well

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bulgogi Plate with Cucumber Kimchi

KjO5-NlaJMd_L4KuXV49QA.text: Had a great pre-symphony lunch here on Sunday with a friend! Opted for the tofu with japchae, and it didn't disappoint! The box meal came with four pieces of crispy tofu with a sweet plum sauce, a generous serving of japchae, salad, tempura vegetables, and choice of banchan (I picked kimchi).   The tofu was delicious and had a great texture, while the plum sauce was sweet and complimented well. The japchae, salad, tempura, and kimchi were great components as well for a filling and well balanced meal. My lunch companion went for the KFC and japchae as well as a Thai iced tea. The chicken and tea were both made very well also, with the KFC being a very large fried chicken cutlet.  I saw they also had tasty looking sides such as bulgogi nachos and sweet potato fries, but we didn't have time to try them this time. Looking forward to going back!

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Crispy Tofu w/ Japchae meal

dXT5S4MepPiFPPOeMrdQGw.text: If you're gluten free, don't come here. I ate here in my previous gluten filled life. I honestly have no doubt it's still delicious. So enjoy it all you people who don't get sick off gluten!   The reason I'm disappointed is because I've talked to the owners multiple times about making items with gluten free soy sauce, and they won't do it. The first time I talked to someone they flat out said, we will never do that because it doesn't taste as good. Dude, I can assure you it will be delicious, I trust your cooking! The last time I talked to them, they said they're now carrying gluten free soy sauce aka tamari sauce, so to come on in. I was PUMPED!  I went up to the counter and the cashier told me the sauce only comes on the side, but they don't make any dishes with the GF sauce still. Why would you offer tamari sauce then? Seems pointless. I could be wrong, but my understanding from what he said is that everything is pre-made and/or marinated in soy sauce. So he told me I can't get anything without gluten except for the plain rice and tofu. Not worth my money. I want the delicious dishes they offer to regular customers!  The reason it's frustrating is because I go to lots of Asian places that can sub in gluten free soy sauce no problem. I actually go to the majority of restaurants in general and they accommodate no issue, with delicious food I might add! I don't want to be gluten free, I have to be so I don't get sick. I just hope at some point they change their minds. With 20% or more of the population having to go gluten free, I'm hoping someday they'll welcome us!

5GacZNEME6z5sYZMRiFZWw.text: Simple menu, easy choices, huge flavors, ginormous portions, great little window seat at which to relax and soak it up.

photos.caption: Photo of Bae Bae's Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Tofu with kimchee

8qstaYbobMWn6_dK2djRQA.text: Traveling with toddlers in the city can be rough, but Bae Bae's awesome staff made a stressful day awesome!  As first time parents, we are always running around getting things, but our awesome cashier was thoughtful and took initiative to offer us a plate for the toddler to use - then when our stroller knocked our bubble tea all over the floor, they were kind enough to help us clean AND bring us a new one!    We felt terrible to put them in chaos right before the lunch rush, but the staff (especially our awesome cashier) were super helpful and he had a smile on the whole time - thank you again & again!    P.S. Food was awesome too, as living in NJ suburbia means we are always trolling for good/unique Asian food when in other cities.  Gotta try the tofu next time, but that wasabi dipping sauce was yummy, and our toddler loved everything from the Korean Fried Chicken to the veggie tempura (and he's a picky eater).  Thanks again!!!

fzahZM5Fo1fRAsbvzCBOlA.text: Fresh food, fast service, and delicious!! There is something for everyone's palate at Bae Bae's. I have never had a bad experience here! Must get the clear noodles and their Vietnamese coffee is the best!!

3POWxnMzmMyHOV6OsABXeA.text: The fried glass noodles are super yummy. The fried chicken is Katsu style. Very crunchy. They offer a delicious and unique honey wasabi sauce for dipping.

dzXEmvbKMH7ECiUw0pIFUA.text: Such a wonderful vibe in here! Super service and excellent food! We had the beef bulgogi and clear noodles. Sooo good and super affordabld. I want to eat here every day and try everything on the menu.

SL6hvHmjjTxOkrfUit8jQg.text: Very underwhelmed, which is unfortunate because it was over-priced.  Lackluster flavors mingled with not-quite-authentic Korean flair made for a pretty dismal experience.  The food is under heat lamps, and served that way.  Nothing seems fresh.   They are lucky that tourists from the convention center and visiting actors from the theater district don't know any better.  They see "Korean" and assume that it is a quality place.   Not to mention the prices...  Waaaaay overpriced for the Bland food. Capital B.   The only possible bright spot is the incredibly "trendy" and disagreeable snowflake workers, who make you wonder if you have annoyed them enough  by forfeiting your money for the crappy food.  Belongs in Lawrenceville, and wouldn't last long there, either.

0lIag5Cf_8J-V0zcRBET7g.text: I stop here about once every two weeks. I get just about everything on the menu plus their Thai iced tea. The food is insanely flavorful and the wait staff is amazing. I've never felt happier than being at Bae Bae's. Not to mention, I've waited extended periods of time for food and not once was I not genuinely thanked for my time. You can take all my money, guys.

pD8q0TKiVxL2cMntwjlVXw.text: Bae bae's is lit. Great vibes with tons of greenery, amazing service, and the best damn lunch stop in the city. Quit reading and go get some damn KFC

owOgsXBIaN8rKvI3JfS19A.text: Absolute go to when it comes to lunch downtown! I can't say enough about the quality of food. I dream about the glass noodles! Love the atmosphere and staff is so friendly. Great vegan option for lunch and there aren't many downtown. Love it!

ptrPXm9_jk8PHF9qVwKELQ.text: This is my first time trying food in here and I am very happy. I ordered glass noodle with KFC along with veggie tempura. The portion is huge for $13~$14. The chicken is really crunchy. I wish I remembered to add hot sauce in the chicken, then it will be perfect. I definitely recommend this place to everyone.

SxKWMyhZhDF5K2GeWiL9pw.text: So, I've been here twice now and both times gotten the same thing. Love Bae Bae's! I got the glass noodles with KFC and Napa kimchi. Also, their iced coffee/tea with boba is awesome. The service is friendly and love the atmosphere! I went with friends on a weekday the first time which I probably won't do again because seating is limited. The second time I went on a Sunday after church around 12pm and the place was dead. Will go back around a similar time next time and get something else totally yummy!

meIkrVaMjElmRi_Vtb5ivA.text: Wow! New favorite Korean place in Pittsburgh. I'm really digging all the Express style restaurants that Pittsburgh has added in this past year. I've been wanted to try it and have heard it's good. Today I came with my friend, and they really don't disappoint. We got there right when they opened on a Saturday, and booooy it's already packed. Popular place! We both got bulgogi and japchae. Not only their food was freshly made and delicious, but their customer service was excellent! The guy that served us was so sweet and helpful. Even though you only get one side, I couldn't decide which side I wanted he let me try one extra side. And we also got to try tempura sweet potatoes. By the time we sat down to eat, there was a line already. I am so excited to bring my other friends here. Also, this place is also dangerously close to where I live. Haha  Next time I want to try their Korean fried chicken or the crispy tofu! Oh my they both look amazing and they seem like the popular options too. It is safe to say I'll definitely be returning sooooon!
